advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>As NEC american office wanted the APC to compete with the IBM PC. So they tried to do a pastiche of the <a href="http://www.old-computers.com/museum/photos.asp?t=2&c=274">Charly Chaplin IBM advert</a>.<br> It was not a good idea.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> LEAFLET #1</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT </strong></font><br><blockquote>One of the first advert for the Atari 520ST checked against an Apple Mac and an Apricot computer. <p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Bradley Sturch</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GENEVA AD, OCT. 1985</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JULY 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Why paying more ?"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> TTX 80 FRENCH ADVERT (JAN. 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"computing against wasted time"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>New Brain complet package with FDD´s and peripherals... (the dot matrix printer was connected to the RS232 port)... The main box you see in the photo is the "school network controller" that permitted that "n" computers were plugged in as a network sharing one "5Mb hard drive"<p class="petitgris">Thanks to Rui Santos for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>The Micro Decision have been presented at the 1983 Hannover show.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT (1986)</strong></font><br><blockquote>November 1986 price list:<br> Monochrome - Single drive: <b>£399</b> + VAT<br> Monochrome - Dual drive: <b>£499</b> + VAT<br> Colour - Single drive: <b>£549</b> + VAT<br> Colour - Dual drive: <b>£649</b> + VAT<br><br> Optional 10 MB hard disk: <b>£300</b> + VAT </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> STRONG WOOMAN(1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Don't beleive this advert!<br> Please, look carefully at the quite horizontal shoulders of the woman who carries the Osborne (about 12 Kg). Either she is a champion of wrestling, or the Osborne case is empty. <br><br> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH LEAFLET</strong></font><br><blockquote>Opening to the computers universe.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 8-PAGE US ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>The display says: "Personal computer Pravetz 82"<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Bojidar Stefanov</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (AUGUST 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Intellivision video games. Intelligence is in the game"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert for Instructor 50, Byte March 1979, Page 45.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to Adam Trinfo for this advert</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (MAY 1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Quite impressive, non ?!<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.page.sannet.ne.jp/sasajima/pc/cata/"><img src="http://www.page.sannet.ne.jp/sasajima/pc/cata/ban_pc1s.gif" border="0"></a> for the picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> STUPID SITUATION</strong></font><br><blockquote>A translation would be : "the 10 years old and more children appreciate quickly the computing principles and have a lot of fun with their ZX-80" <br><br> So they say...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> BROCHURE</strong></font><br><blockquote>This french brochure presented games from #1 to #43</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT #4(1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The users featured in the ad said:<br><br> (left) <i>Programming is a snap! I'm halfway through Apple's BASIC manual and already I've programmed my own Star Wars game.</i><br><br> ...with half of the universe<br><br> (middle) <i>Those math programs I wrote last week - I just rewrote them using Apple's mini assembler and got them to run a hundred time faster.</i><br><br> Of course, it's very easy for a newbie programmer to program maths assembly routines with a microprocessor which only knows how to add and subtract integer values.<br><br> (right)<i>Apple's smart peripherals make expansion easy. Just plug'em it and you are ready to run. I've already added two disks, a printer and a communication card.</i></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK BROCHURE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT (OCTOBER 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Goupil plays on all tables"</blockquote>

computer.builtInGames: Tank Combat game with 4 variations (Combat, Night Battle, Robot Battle, Camouflage Combat)
computer.description:
An original system with it's army design. It plays a classic combat game found on some of "Pong generation" systems... The two player game and its 4 variations are built-in the AY-3-8700-1 chipset from General Instruments. This game could also be found on some cartridge systems based on the GI chipsets.
The two-handed joystick controls simulate the commands, just like in a real tank. Each set is fitted with a fire button on top of the right stick. There is a reset button, an on/off switch and game selection switch (from 1 to 4). There are even suction cup feet to secure the console to the table.
It's got two seperate HP, one for tank engine sounds and the other one for weapon firing sounds.
Promotional sentences: - Play 4 video tank gams with realistic battle sounds - Digital display scoring and realistic batlle sounds - Play 4 video tank games at the flick of a switch - Dual throttle controllers with firing button - Advertised on TV
computer.keyboard: 4 sticks (2 tank controllers) with fire buttons
computer.language: Tank Combat game with 4 variations (Combat, Night Battle, Robot Battle, Camouflage Combat)
computer.name: Combat!
